title: 112_hr6677
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Common Sense Housing Investment Act of 2012". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress acknowledges the disparity in achieving the goals of increasing home ownership and providing affordable rental housing. There is a significant imbalance in budgetary resources allocated towards supporting home ownership compared to affordable rental housing. Renters face a greater burden of housing costs, with a shortage of nearly 7 million affordable homes for low-income families. Only a quarter of eligible families receive rental housing assistance. Public housing facilities in the United States have over $26 billion in deferred maintenance, leading to the loss of 10,000 units annually. The low-income housing tax credit provides 100,000 affordable housing units each year. Tax reform commissions suggest capping the mortgage interest deduction, as it primarily benefits the top 20% of earners. Less than half of tax filers with a home mortgage claim this deduction. Only 9 percent of rural tax filers claim the mortgage interest deduction, with 96 percent of homes sold between 2000 and 2009 selling for less than $500,000. A better approach is needed to provide equitable benefits for families buying homes, assist low- and moderate-income homeowners, and invest in affordable rental housing for those in need. SEC. 3. REPLACEMENT OF MORTGAGE INTEREST DEDUCTION WITH MORTGAGE INTEREST CREDIT. This section introduces a nonrefundable credit for interest on indebtedness secured by a qualified residence. The tax code allows a 20 percent credit for qualified residence interest paid by individuals. Qualified residence interest includes acquisition and home equity indebtedness on the taxpayer's qualified residence. The determination of qualified residence is made at the time the interest is accrued. The tax code limits the aggregate amount of indebtedness for qualified residence interest to $500,000 ($250,000 for married individuals filing separately). Acquisition indebtedness refers to debt incurred in acquiring, constructing, or improving a qualified residence, secured by the residence, including refinanced debt meeting these criteria. The tax code limits qualified residence interest indebtedness to $500,000 ($250,000 for married individuals filing separately), including acquisition indebtedness for acquiring, constructing, or improving a qualified residence. Home equity indebtedness is any debt secured by a qualified residence, not exceeding the fair market value reduced by acquisition indebtedness. The aggregate home equity indebtedness cannot exceed $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals). The tax code limits qualified residence interest indebtedness to $500,000 ($250,000 for married individuals filing separately). A qualified residence includes the principal residence and one other selected by the taxpayer for the taxable year. Married couples not filing jointly are treated as one taxpayer for this purpose. The tax code allows individuals to consider one principal residence and one other residence for qualified residence interest indebtedness. If a taxpayer does not rent a dwelling unit during the taxable year, it can still be treated as a residence. Security interests cannot be disregarded solely due to ineffective enforceability under state or local laws. The tax code allows individuals to consider one principal residence and one other residence for qualified residence interest indebtedness. Security interests cannot be disregarded solely due to ineffective enforceability under state or local laws. Special rules apply for estates and trusts regarding qualified residence interest. Taxpayers may elect to apply this section instead of the deduction under section 163 for qualified residence interest. Phaseout of the deduction is also addressed in the code. The tax code allows individuals to consider one principal residence and one other residence for qualified residence interest indebtedness. Security interests cannot be disregarded solely due to ineffective enforceability under state or local laws. Special rules apply for estates and trusts regarding qualified residence interest. Taxpayers may elect to apply this section instead of the deduction under section 163 for qualified residence interest. A phaseout of the deduction is addressed in the code after 2012. The applicable percentage for qualified residence interest indebtedness varies based on the calendar year, starting at 100% in 2013 and decreasing to 0% in 2018 and thereafter. The mortgage limit for taxable years 2013 through 2017 will be phased down, with specified amounts replacing the original limits of $1,000,000 and $500,000. The mortgage limit for taxable years 2013 through 2017 will be phased down, with specified amounts replacing the original limits. The mortgage limit for taxable years 2013 through 2017 will be phased down, with specified amounts replacing the original limits: 
2013 - $1,000,000 substituted for $500,000
2014 - $900,000 substituted for $450,000
2015 - $800,000 substituted for $400,000
2016 - $700,000 substituted for $350,000
2017 - $600,000 substituted for $300,000. The amendments made by this section relate to interest on indebtedness secured by qualified residence and deduction allowed for interest and taxes relating to land for dwelling purposes owned or leased by cooperative housing corporations. The effective dates for these changes are after December 31, 2012. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the $2,000,000 amount in subparagraph (C) by a cost-of-living adjustment for calendar years after 2002. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the $2,000,000 amount in subparagraph (C) for calendar years after 2002. For calendar years after 2013, the $2.70 amount in subparagraph (C) will be adjusted based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the $2,000,000 amount in subparagraph (C) for calendar years after 2002. The $2.70 amount in subparagraph (C) will be adjusted based on the cost-of-living adjustment for calendar years after 2013. Clause (i) of section 42(d)(5)(B) is amended regarding eligible basis. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the $2,000,000 amount in subparagraph (C) for calendar years after 2002. The $2.70 amount in subparagraph (C) will be adjusted based on the cost-of-living adjustment for calendar years after 2013. Clause (i) of section 42(d)(5)(B) is amended regarding eligible basis by adding a new provision for buildings designated to serve extremely low-income households. The amendments made by this section will apply to allocations made in calendar years beginning after December 31, 2012. SEC. 6. USE OF MORTGAGE INTEREST SAVINGS FOR AFFORDABLE HOUSING PROGRAMS. The Secretary of the Treasury will determine revenues from the enactment of section 3 of the Act. Remaining revenues will be credited to the Housing Trust Fund and Section 8 rental assistance. The Secretary will credit remaining revenues to the Public Housing Capital Fund and revise regulations for the Housing Trust Fund to maximize flexibility. The Secretary will revise regulations for the Housing Trust Fund to increase flexibility, allow more recipients for grants, and eliminate rules based on the HOME Investment Partnerships Act.
